content:
• Tuesday, March 14, 2017
  • AXAS

    Abraxas Petroleum +13% AH as Q4 brings surprise profit

    • Abraxas Petroleum (NASDAQ:AXAS) +12.7% AH after reporting a surprise adjusted Q4 profit on a 64% Y/Y improvement in revenues, results the company calls “superb” in the face of difficult markets last year.
    • AXAS says 2016 cash operating expenses came in toward the lower end of its guidance range, and January 2017 financial results continue to reflect the improvement with cash expenses coming in at the low end of guidance; the company says it also has seen a "tremendous improvement" in natural gas and natural gas liquids realizations in January.
    • AXAS says its balance sheet and cash flow position will allow it to execute its program to run a full-time rig in both the Bakken and Permian plays, and it continues to "pursue several cost-effective bolt-on acquisition opportunities" in the Delaware Basin.
     
     
     
     
    | 6:36 PM | 8 Comments

  • After Hours Gainers / Losers

    • Top gainers, as of 5.25 p.m.: RST +12.2%. TCON +11.1%. MUX +5.0%. CLDX +4.2%. RRC +3.2%.
    • Top losers, as of 5.25p.m.: RUBI -13.6%. NPTN -13.4%. NMM -12.0%. AKAO -9.5%. FTD -8.8%.

  • NMM

    Navios Maritime to sell 47.6M units in direct offering at $2.10 each

    • Navios Maritime Partners (NYSE:NMM) -11.6% AH  after announcing plans to sell ~47.6M common units in a direct offering at $2.10/unit, which equates to a 16% discount to today's closing price.
    • NMM expects proceeds from the offering of ~$95M, which the company says will be used for general working capital purposes, including vessel acquisitions.
     
     
     
     
    | 5:22 PM | 49 Comments
  • ARNA

    Arena's Q4 beat gooses shares, up 23% after hours

    • Arena Pharmaceuticals (NASDAQ:ARNA) Q4 results ($M): Revenues: 85.4 (+999%); Eisai Collaboration Revenue: 61.5 (+999%); BELVIQ Sales: 26.3 (+317.9%).
    • Net Income: 38.6 (+999%); EPS: 0.16 (+223.1%).
    • 2017 Guidance: Cash utilization: $80M - 100M.
    • The big bump in Eisai-related revenues came from its acquisition of global rights to BELVIQ.
    • Consensus views for EPS and revenues were ($0.08) and $15.6M, respectively.
     
     
     
     
    | 4:57 PM | 5 Comments
  • NPTN

    NeoPhotonics -12%; Q1 2017 outlook off considerably

    • Q4 2016 results – revenue $109.8M (+23.2% Y/Y, $2.88M above estimates), EPS $0.13 ($0.05 above estimates)
    • Q1 2017 projections – revenue $67M-$73M (consensus $98.04M), EPS -$0.20 to -$0.30 (consensus $0.05), gross margin 28%-31%, operating expenses $29M-$31M
    • After hours – (NYSE:NPTN) $7.10

  • GOGL

    Golden Ocean to buy 16 dry bulk vessels in cash and stock deal

    • Golden Ocean (NASDAQ:GOGL) -5.9% AH after agreeing to acquire 16 modern dry bulk vessels, 14 from subsidiaries of Quintana Shipping and two ice class Panamax vessels from subsidiaries of Seatankers, an affiliate of Hemen Holding, the company's largest shareholder.
    • In connection with the acquisition, GOGL will issue 17.8M shares and assume $285.2M of debt, and launches an equity offering of new shares for gross proceeds of ~$60M.
     
     
     
     
    | 4:48 PM | 4 Comments
  • AKAO

    Achaogen's Q4 miss pressures shares, down 11% after hours

    • Achaogen (NASDAQ:AKAO) Q4 results ($M): Revenues: 10.7 (+127.7%).
    • Net Loss: (29.7) (-162.8%); Loss/Share: (1.04) (-70.5%).
    • Shares are down 11% after revenues came in under consensus of $12.4M and the loss/share was worse than expected ($0.49).
     
     
     
     
    | 4:42 PM | 4 Comments

  • Oil gains after hours on bullish supply report

    • The API has reported a 531K barrel decline in crude stocks vs. estimates for a 3M barrel build. It would be the first weekly decline since late last year.
    • USO +1% after hours
    • ETFs: USO, OIL, UCO, SCO, BNO, DBO, DTO, UGA, USL, DNO, OLO, UHN, SZO, OLEM, DWT, OILK, OILX, UWT
     
     
     
     
    | 4:41 PM | 30 Comments
  • RUBI

    Rubicon Project guides low, slips 13.6% after earnings

    • Rubicon Project (RUBI -2%) has tumbled in postmarket trading, down 13.6%, after Q4 earnings that beat expectations but contained downbeat guidance for the coming quarter.
    • Revenue dropped 20% Y/Y and the company swung to a GAAP net loss of $21.2M (from a year-ago profit of $20.4M), with the help of an impairment charge of $23.5M.
    • EBITDA of $21.7M fell nearly 40% but beat an expected $15.7M.
    • The company named its new CEO, former Millennial Media chief Michael Barrett.
    • "As we move into 2017, we remain focused on signing up more publishers, application developers, and adding inventory to our global exchange, a key component to drive future growth," said CEO Frank Addante.
    • For Q1, it's guiding to non-GAAP net revenue of $41M-$44M, light of consensus for $57.3M; adjusted EBITDA of -$6M to -$4M, vs. expectations for an EBITDA gain of $8.2M, and non-GAAP EPS of -$0.26 to -$0.22 vs. an expected per-share profit of $0.10.
    • Press Release
     
     
     
     
    | 4:35 PM | 17 Comments
  • FOGO

    Fogo de Chao higher after guidance satisfies

    • Fogo de Chao (NASDAQ:FOGO) pops after Q4 results arrive slightly ahead of expectations.
    • Comparable restaurant sales were down 1.0% in the U.S. during the quarter. Brazil restaurant revenue was flat at $12.2M.
    • Restaurant contribution margin fell 290 bps to 31.4%.
    • Initial guidance from the company for 2017 is for revenue of $315M to $320M vs. $318M consensus and EPS to fall in a range of $0.92 to $0.95 vs. $0.92 consensus. Fogo expects to open seven restaurants this year.
    • Previously: Fogo de Chao beats by $0.01, beats on revenue (March 14)
    • FOGO +7.92% AH to $14.30.
     
     
     
     
    | 4:23 PM | 2 Comments
  • UTHR

    United Therapeutics down 3% over possible delay in Remodulin infusion pump

    • United Therapeutics (NASDAQ:UTHR) was under pressure today, down 3% on light volume, on a possible delay in releasing a programmable infusion pump for Remodulin (treprostinil) users.
    • RBC's Michael Yee says the heightened risk comes from Medtronic's (NYSE:MDT) recall of its SynchroMed II/EL pumps due to a priming bolus issue, which it plans to fix with a software update. A year ago, the FDA rejected Medtronic's marketing application for an implantable pump to deliver Remodulin. The pulmonary arterial hypertension med faces generic competition in 2018 so a delay in offering an implantable pump option would make it more difficult for UTHR to protect sales.
    • Source: Bloomberg
     
     
     
     
    | 4:18 PM | 1 Comment

  • CORV

    Cardiome cleared to commercialize Brinavess in Canada; shares ahead 2%

    • Thinly traded nano cap Cardiome Pharma (CRME +2%) heads north on triple normal volume, albeit on turnover of only 94K shares, in response to its announcement that it has received a Notice of Compliance for BRINAVESS (vernakalant hydrochloride, IV) from Health Canada which enables the company to begin commercializing the product there.
    • BRINAVESS is indicated for the rapid conversion of recent-onset atrial fibrillation to sinus rhythm in certain patients.
    • Cardiome plans to meet with the FDA next month related to advancing development in the U.S. Vernakalant IV has been on clinical hold since 2010.
     
     
     
     
    | 3:59 PM
  • EQNR

    Statoil reports gas leak at Asgard field

    • Statoil (STO -2.5%) says it has launched an investigation into a gas leak at its Åsgard field offshore Norway in which 25 tons of natural gas leaked out during well preparations.
    • It is just the latest in string of safety incidents for STO; last week, Norway's PSA safety authority found the company in breach of regulations in a fire that broke out on a North Sea platform after crude oil pumped against a closed valve for nearly an hour.
    • The Asgard field is one of the largest developments offshore Norway, with 63 production and injection wells drilled through 19 subsea templates.
     
     
     
     
    | 3:58 PM
  • TSRO

    TESARO (-14%) and Clovis (+10%) go opposite ways on AstraZeneca's Lynparza data

    • Positive data from a Phase 3 clinical trial of AstraZeneca's PARP inhibitor Lynparza has TESARO (TSRO -13.6%) reeling and Clovis Oncology (CLVS +10.4%) rocking.
    • TESARO is slumping because Lynparza's benefit as maintenance therapy in ovarian cancer may be a bit better than its PARP candidate niraparib. Its U.S. marketing application is currently under FDA review for a broader indication than Lynparza.
    • Clovis is rallying because investors believe the positive data will goose sales of PARP inhibitor Rubraca (rucaparib), OK'd by the FDA to treat ovarian cancer in December 2016.
     
     
     
     
    | 3:46 PM | 16 Comments
  • HLIT

    Harmonic -5.1% as Drexel returns to sidelines

    • Harmonic (NASDAQ:HLIT) is 5.1% lower today on heavy volume after Drexel Hamilton has headed to the sidelines on the stock.
    • The firm's Greg Mesniaeff downgraded Harmonic to Hold from a previous Buy rating. Drexel had previously bumped it from Hold to Buy in August.
    • Harmonic is up 0.9% since it beat expectations with earnings at February's end, and hit a 52-week high last Wednesday.
    • It's up 11% YTD and up 76.8% over the past 12 months.
     
     
     
     
    | 3:43 PM | 2 Comments
  • MRO

    Marathon Oil reiterated Hold at Canaccord after sharp loss

    • Marathon Oil (MRO -3.3%) has given up all its gains that followed last Thursday's news that it sold all its interests in Canada's Athbasca oil sands for $2.5B and bought 70K net surface acres in the Permian Basin for $1.1B.
    • Canaccord Genuity reiterates its Hold rating and $17 price target on the shares, calling the exit from Canada a “win-win” both for MRO and for buyers Royal Dutch Shell and Canadian Natural Resources.
    • The firm says the Canada exit simplifies MRO's portfolio while shifting to lower cost, higher margin resource plays in the U.S., represents a 15x multiple on 2016 operating cash flow, eliminates material future capex requirements for a non-operated asset and - including the Permian acquisition - is expected to result in a 25% reduction in total operating expenses in 2017.
    • Canaccord also highlights MRO’s strong financial position, noting that total liquidity at year-end 2016 equaled $5.8B and will bump up to ~$7.2B following the two transactions.
     
     
     
     
    | 3:42 PM | 7 Comments
  • AZN

    AstraZeneca's Lynparza shows significant survival benefit in late-stage ovarian cancer study; shares ahead 1%

    • Results from a Phase 3 clinical trial, SOLO-2, assessing AstraZeneca's (AZN +1%) PARP inhibitor Lynparza (olaparib) as maintenance therapy in ovarian cancer showed a pronounced extension in survival compared to placebo. The data were presented at the Society of Gynecologic Oncology meeting in National Harbor, MD.
    • The study met its primary endpoint of a statistically significant improvement in progression-free survival (PFS) versus placebo. Patients receiving Lynparza experienced median PFS of 19.1 months compared to 5.5 months for placebo (p<0.0001). When measured by blinded independent central review, the difference was even more dramatic: 30.2 months vs. 5.5 months (p<0.0001).
    • The Lynparza cohort also demonstrated a statistically significant benefit in time to second progression or death (p=0.0002) (hazard ratio = 0.50) (median not reached vs. 18.4 months).
    • The safety profile for participants treated with Lynparza tablets was generally consistent with those observed with the currently approved capsule formulation.
    • The company plans to work with regulators to make the tablet formulation available to patients as soon as feasible since tablets reduce the pill burden to four/day from 16/day.
     
     
     
     
    | 3:35 PM | 3 Comments

  • Treasurys catch a bid ahead of rate hike

    • The FOMC today began its two-day policy meeting, the result of which is universally expected to be a 25 basis point rate hike tomorrow.
    • The language in the policy statement will be of interest, as will the updated economic projections, the "dots," and Yellen's press conference. Have expectations at the central bank shifted from three rate hikes this year to four?
    • Also interesting is that the rate hike will be coming amid a fairly quick plunge in the price of oil - down more than $6 per barrel this month. The Fed could be upping its growth, inflation, and interest rate forecasts at just the moment when oil is signaling the opposite.
    • The 10-year yield today has backed off three basis points to 2.59%. TLT +0.6%, TBT -1.2%
    • Previously: Oil tumbles to new lows as Saudis report boosted output (March 14)
    • ETFs: TBT, TLT, TMV, TBF, EDV, TMF, TTT, ZROZ, VGLT, TLH, UBT, DLBS, TLO, VUSTX, DLBL, TYBS
     
     
     
     
    | 3:19 PM | 11 Comments

  • MMM

    3M dips during conference presentation

    • There's no webcast thanks to the storm, but the JPMorgan Aviation, Transportation, and Industrials Conference goes on in NYC.
    • 3M (MMM -0.7%) CFO Nick Gangestad takes note of softness in the company's consumer unit early this year. Industrial and electronics units, on the other hand, are off to a strong start.
    • Looking south, there's strength in Mexico, but uncertainty in Brazil.
    • Shares fell more than 1% as his remarks hit the tape, currently down 0.65%.
    • Source: Bloomberg
     
     
     
     
    | 2:26 PM
  • HAL

    Halliburton has plenty of reasons to seek Aker Solutions, analyst says

    • Reports that Halliburton (HAL -2.2%) is near a deal to buy Aker Solutions are dismissed by Aker ASA, RBC analyst Kurt Hallead sees some compelling reasons why HAL might be interested in the Norwegian oil services company.
    • Aker would give HAL a similar product suite as chief competitors Schlumberger (SLB -0.1%) and Baker Hughes (BHI -0.3%)/General Electric (GE -1.2%), Hallead says, adding that a deal could make sense from a competitive framework but that HAL has never indicated that it felt subsea was a missing piece to its product and service offering.
     
     
     
     
    | 2:26 PM

  • Traders up hedging efforts as oil's slide continues

    • The price of crude oil is down yet again today, and at $47.62, hitting its lowest level since November.
    • The move is leading to a sizable pickup in put volume on energy-focused ETFs, according to Bloomberg.
    • Looking at the SPDR S&P Oil & Gas Exploration & Production ETF (NYSEARCA:XOP), put volume is nearly triple the 20-day average and more than 5x call trades.
    • As for oil itself, put volume on the USO is double the 20-day moving average and double call trades.
    • Previously: Oil tumbles to new lows as Saudis report boosted output (March 14)
     
     
     
     
    | 2:02 PM | 1 Comment
  • WBA

    Walgreens working to sell more stores to Fred's - Bloomberg

    • Bloomberg reports that Walgreen Boots Alliance (WBA -0.7%) is working on a deal to sell more stores to Fred's (FRED +2.5%) in order to gain regulatory acceptance for its Rite Aid (RAD +3%) merger.
    • Shares of Fred's and Rite Aid have broken higher in the last 30 minutes off the development.
     
     
     
     
    | 1:57 PM | 129 Comments
  • SHAK

    Winter storm impact gauged

    • Shake Shack (NYSE:SHAK) is down 7.25% over the last few sessions as investors may be gauging the impact of the widespread East Coast snow on the company's Q1 sales.
    • Maxim estimates that 70% of Shake Shack's revenue is from the U.S. Northeast.
    • Dunkin' Brands (NASDAQ:DNKN) has almost the same exposure, but is only 1.4% lower over the same time period.
    • A flip side to strong storms is the impact on restaurant demand if widespread power outages occur. Chains such as Domino's Pizza (DPZ -1.9%) and Papa John's International (PZZA -0.8%) have reported outage-related sales bursts in the past
     
     
     
     
    | 1:44 PM

  • Small caps give up 2017 gains

    • This just in: Down another 0.85% today, the Russell 2000 has returned to flat on the year vs. 5%+ gains for the Dow and S&P 500 and an 8.7% advance for the Nasdaq. Is the divergence something to worry about?
    • On a year-over-year basis, the Russell 2000 remains in the lead, up 25% vs. 23% for the Nasdaq, 21% for the Dow, and 17% for the S&P 500.

    Healthcare stocks under water as GOP tries to advance ACA replacement

    • Healthcare stocks are under pressure today as Republicans ares trying to deflect criticism over their plan to dismantle the Affordable Care Act which, according to the Congressional Budget Office (CBO), will cause 14M Americans to lose health insurance coverage.

  • BIOC

    Catalyst Pharma to offer Biocept's liquid biopsy test in late-stage LEMS study; shares of both ahead 3%

    • Biocept (BIOC +3.4%) announces a collaboration with Catalyst Pharmaceuticals (CPRX +3.1%) under which it will provide its Target Selector platform to screen participants in a Phase 3 study assessing Firdapse (amifampridine phosphate) in patients with Eaton Myasthenic Syndrome (LEMS).
    • Specifically, Catalyst will offer the test at no charge to patients to monitor the early onset or recurrence of small cell lung cancer (SCLC) during the long-term extension phase of the trial. Subjects will have access to the liquid biopsy test every six months for up to two years.
    • About half of LEMS patients have a form of the disease that is associated with an increased risk of developing SCLC. Approximately 90% of these patients develop tumors within two years of the LEMS diagnosis.
    • Terms of the agreement are not disclosed.
    • Previously: Enrollment underway in Catalyst Pharma's second late-stage study of Firdapse in LEMS (Dec. 15, 2016)
     
     
     
     
    | 12:08 PM | 5 Comments
  • CIE

    Cobalt Energy -15% on wider than expected Q4 loss

    • Cobalt Energy (CIE -14.8) plunges to 52-week lows after reporting a Q4 loss of $0.43/share, excluding $4.04 in non-recurring items, $0.28 worse than the analyst consensus estimate of a $0.15 loss.
    • CIE says its North Platte #4 appraisal well in the deepwater Gulf of Mexico encountered ~650 ft. of net oil pay, with initial results indicating high quality reservoirs on the field's eastern flank of the field; appraisal operations continue at North Platte, where CIE recently completed drilling of the North Platte #4 sidetrack well to further analyze the extent of the eastern flank.
    • For 2017, CIE forecasts $275M in capex, cash outlays of $550M-$650M and $50M in net revenue.
     
     
     
     
    | 11:58 AM | 3 Comments
  • TECK

    Teck Resources may have most to gain if zinc refiners squeezed

    • Teck Resources (TECK -1.7%) could gain the most of any mining company if a supply shortfall in zinc forces smelters to cut the fees they charge miners to refine the metal, Bloomberg reports.
    • Should talks between miners and smelters result in lower processing fees, Teck stands to benefit from its surplus in unprocessed ore, and that gain would come in addition to the tailwind the company already enjoys from higher prices for zinc and the other commodities it sells.
    • Teck CEO Don Lindsay says talks to set benchmark processing fees this year are likely to result in the “largest decrease in treatment charges in modern history.”
     
     
     
     
    | 11:45 AM | 1 Comment

  • REPCF

    RepliCel's autologous cell therapy candidate to treat hair loss safe in long-term study; shares ease 5% on long development timeline

    • Thinly traded nano cap ReliCel Life Sciences (OTCQB:REPCF -5.1%)  slips after it announced data from a five-year Phase 1 study assessing the safety of its autologous cell therapy for the treatment of androgenic alopecia (pattern baldness), RCH-01. The results were fine, but the timeline for the next study has apparently dampened investors' enthusiasm.
    • The 19-subject trial met its endpoints thereby confirming the complete safety profile of a high dose of dermal sheath cup cells, administered via injection, for patients with pattern baldness.
    • Although not powered for efficacy, a treatment effect was observed. The seven best responders experienced at least a 10% increase versus baseline in hair density six months after injection. At month 24, the average hair density increase in the same seven subjects was 8.3%. The top responder showed a 21% increase in hair density at month 24.
    • The company intends to advance RCH-01 into a Phase 2 study in 160 healthy men with mild-to-moderate pattern baldness. Dermal sheath cup cells will be isolated from a small punch biopsy taken from the back of the subject's scalp. The cells will be replicated and then reintroduced into balding areas. Participants will remain on study for ~39 months.
     
     
     
     
    | 11:41 AM | 4 Comments
  • XAN

    Resource Capital +6% after earnings

    • Q4 core loss of $3.7M or $0.12 per share; full-year core loss of $1M and $0.03. Q4 dividend was $0.05.
    • Dec. 31 book value per share of $14.17 vs. $14.71 in Q3, and down from $17.63 a year earlier. Current price after today's gain is $8.61.
    • New loans originated during quarter of $50.6M; after payoffs and principal paydowns, net loans down $9.1M for quarter and $116.3M for year.
    • Earnings call transcript

  • GXYEF

    Double-digit revenue growth expected in Macau this month

    • Hong Kong-traded Macau names moved higher today after JPMorgan issued a positive forecast on Macau revenue trends for March.
    • JP says the VIP segment is tracking at a high teens growth rate and the mass market segment is up at a low-to-mid teens growth pace.   • GALT

    Galectin reports positive preliminary results in small study of GR-MD-02 in treatment-resistant eczema; shares ahead 2%

    • Galectin Therapeutics (GALT +2.2%) is steadily clawing its way back from a Q4 plunge after lead product candidate GR-MD-02 flunked a mid-stage NASH study. Investors have warmed to the sock after the product candidate showed potential in severe skin disorders like plaque psoriasis. Shares have almost doubled since late January.
    • Today, the company announced encouraging early results from a small, open-label, investigator-initiated study of GR-MD-02 in three patients with severe and refractory atopic dermatitis (AD). All three responded to therapy, with two achieving 64% and 74% reductions, respectively, in a measure of AD symptoms called EASI score.
    • CEO Peter G. Traber, M.D. says, “We are pleased by the results of this study demonstrating the safety and clinically significant effect in patients with severe atopic dermatitis, although because of the potential of a placebo effect in this disease, confirmation of the magnitude of the effect will require placebo-controlled trials. Moreover, the activity of GR-MD-02 in these patients compares favorably with other drugs currently in development, and with minimal side effects as demonstrated by nearly 3,000 doses of our compound being administered in multiple completed and ongoing clinical trials with no severe adverse effects attributed to the drug.”
    • GR-MD-02 is a complex carbohydrate drug that targets galectin-3, a protein that plays a key role in the pathogenesis of fatty liver disease and fibrosis.

  • RSLS

    EnteroMedics' vBloc featured on TV show; shares ahead 21% premarket

    • EnteroMedics (ETRM) is up 21% premarket on average volume in apparent response to the news that its vBloc Therapy will be featured on a daytime talk show called "The Doctors" today. Frank Chae, M.D., FACS, Chief Surgeon and Head of the Bariatric Center at Sky Ridge Medical Center in Colorado and one his patients who received vBloc to treat her obesity will discuss the benefits of the system and her battle to control her weight.
    • The company's Maestro vBloc is a pacemaker-like device that delivers vagal nerve blocking therapy via electrodes that are surgically implanted subcutaneously in the abdomen. The electrodes are placed in contact with the trunks of the vagus nerves just above the junction between the esophagus and the stomach. The device intermittently blocks vagal nerve signals throughout the patient's waking hours which produces the sensation of fullness.

    • Investors in Valeant Pharmaceuticals (VRX) continue to follow hedge fund honcho Bill Ackman to the exits. Shares are down 12% premarket on robust volume.
    • Ackman's Pershing Square Capital Management, L.P. could have lost over $5B from its ill-fated investment in the beaten-down drug firm. Pershing last owned 27,234,432 shares, which were sold at $11 for proceeds just shy of $300M. In March 2015, it owned 34,118,551 shares and derivatives when the stock was at $200 (>$6.8B) so the shares just liquidated were valued at ~$5.45B, implying a loss of ~$5.15B.
    • At its current value, Pershing stated that its Valeant position represented 1.5 - 3.0% of its funds, but required an inordinate amount of time and resources so it elected to sell and realize the tax loss.
    • Mr. Ackman and Pershing Vice Chairman Steve Fraidin will remain on Valeant's board until the Annual Meeting but will not stand for re-election.
